p: Unfortunately, up to now, no cure for diabetes is available, but it can be controlled by a proper management of blood sugar levels via the consumption of a healthy diet, physical exercises, and usage of multiple synthetic antidiabetic agents, which can reduce the risk of long-term diabetes complications [ 7]. However, the effectiveness of these synthetic antidiabetic agents is limited because of detrimental adverse effects including flatulence, diarrhea, stomach ache, hypoglycemia, damage of liver, drug resistance, gaining weight, and heart disorder coupled with the high cost of drugs [ 8, 9]. Therefore, there is a significant need for producing natural antidiabetic products/drugs with a high safety margin. Medicinal plants and natural products have been employed as sources of medicine since ancient times for alleviating human suffering [ 10], and plants are well known to be the principal source of health-promoting secondary metabolites including terpenoids, flavonoids, polyphenols, and several other valuable constituents, which are responsible for several health promoting effects such as antidiabetic activity [ 11].
